summary: Internal email chain among U.S. Department of Justice and State Department officials discussing press strategy and legal considerations regarding a reported MLAT request to question Prince Andrew in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The chain includes discussion of Prince Andrew's legal team's public criticism of DOJ and the need for coordinated messaging.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: Subject of MLAT request, Duke of York
persons.context: The Duke of York, whose legal team has publicly criticized the DOJ's handling of the Epstein investigation and claims he has offered to help multiple times. The DOJ is reportedly seeking to question him via an MLAT request.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: Mentioned as having made statements in January and March that Prince Andrew was not cooperating with the Epstein investigation, which Prince Andrew's lawyers claim are inaccurate.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, made public statements about Prince Andrew's lack of cooperation in the Epstein probe, which Andrew's legal team disputes.

events.title: Prince Andrew's legal team issues statement criticizing DOJ
events.description: Prince Andrew's legal team releases a statement accusing the DOJ of mishandling his offers to assist in the Epstein investigation, claiming he has offered to help at least three times in 2020 and that DOJ statements have been inaccurate and breached confidentiality.

events.title: U.S. Attorney Berman's statement on Prince Andrew's cooperation
events.description: Geoffrey Berman, U.S. Attorney, states that Prince Andrew was not cooperating with the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

events.title: Second statement by U.S. Attorney Berman
events.description: Geoffrey Berman makes another statement regarding Prince Andrew's lack of cooperation in the Epstein probe.

keyFacts: Prince Andrew's legal team publicly accused the DOJ of rejecting his offers to assist in the Epstein investigation at least three times in 2020 and of breaching confidentiality rules.
The Sun newspaper reported that the DOJ made a formal MLAT request to the UK Home Office to question Prince Andrew in the Epstein criminal probe.
U.S. officials internally debated press strategy, with a standard stance of not confirming or denying the existence of investigations or MLAT communications.
The situation was considered enormously sensitive due to Prince Andrew's royal status, the parallel Harry Dunn/Anne Sacoolas extradition case, and questions of sovereign immunity.
Internal emails reveal concern that the U.S. Embassy in London was not informed in advance about the alleged MLAT request, leaving them unprepared for press inquiries.
